title: Before 1 July 2017, will a date be set for early general elections in the United Kingdom?
preds: This wasn't even front page on my FT.com yesterday :-(

Snap election approved by MPs
The general election will be held on 8 June after MPs supported Theresa May's motion - with just 13 MPs voting against.
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39643804
Well ok got this one totally wrong to jumping to 100 because it's been called. This will hurt.
Oopsie. This score is going to hurt. http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-39629603?
Theresa May called snap elections. Vote to be held in Parliament tomorrow. Very likely successful. Conservative's, Lib Dems, and Labour likely to vote in favour.
As far as political U-turns go, this was rather quick. In hindsight, the move makes sense, as most hindsight views :). Looking at my forecasts, I draw two lessons:
Wow. I did not see this coming.
May Chases an Early U.K. Election in Gamble for Brexit Unity
Now, I'm reading that Labour won't oppose a vote to dissolve Parliament, which is scheduled to be taken on Wednesday.

It is in June!
"May said she changed her mind on a recent walking holiday with her husband in Wales."
The invasion of the Flip Floppers 6!

Theresa May has today called for General Elections to take place on 8th June. The surprise call comes as the Conservatives are riding high in opinion polls at the expense of Jeremy Corbyn’s decimated, extremist Labour Party. Following the triggering of Article 50 last month, Theresa May has garnered support for making good on her promise to deliver Brexit. Her steadfast stance on Gibraltar also suggests she’s not going to concede to the bleats from limp-wristed Europhiles for ‘Brexit-light’.

I stupidly believed Mrs May when she ruled out an election before 2020. 
She presumably changed her mind because she realises that the UK economy is starting to turn down (after unexpectedly holding  up for 9 months, it now looks like the Brexit reaction is starting). She must be realising that the various "opportunities" of  Brexit are contradictory (e.g. more freetrade while losing freetrade with the UK's main trading partner; deals with EU while not accepting the ECJ; an open border between Eire and Northern Ireland while leaving the EU Customs Union and not allowing the Freedom of Movement of People; leaving the EU and economic growth.) And that between now and 2020 choosing between these contradictory option is not going to satisfy those who voted for Brexit or those who voted to Remain. 
In other words she can see the storm coming and has anticipated that the populist mob will be crying "betrayal" in the next couple of years. Rather than be thrown out as the unelected leader that crashed the economy in 2020 she wants to be a leader who won one election and can hang on until 2022.   
It is going to be very difficult forecasting this election although the local elections on May 4th will give good clues. "Remain" Conservative supporters will likely switch to the LibDems. "Remain" Labour supporters could switch to the Greens or LibDems; many UKIP supporters might return to the Conservatives. Many Conservative seats might go to the LibDems; Labour will probably loose a lot of seats.  
It does raise the question of why she triggered A50 in March? It means that several months of what it has been agreed is a very tight timetable for the Brexit negotiations will be wasted (but we already guessed that much).

May just announced this. This is dependent on the fixed term Parliament act, which requires a 2/3 majority in a vote. Labour MPs, who will vote independently of Corbyn, could vote this down. But we will know tomorrow. A shame I was not looking at this sooner.
Whelp. I got this one incredibly wrong
@Khalid Yes I am going to do very, very badly on this question.

BREAKING NEWS
Prime Minister Theresa May has called an early election for June, seeking a bigger mandate as Britain prepares to leave the E.U.
Tuesday, April 18, 2017 6:14 AM EDT
Prime Minister Theresa May stunned Britain on Tuesday by announcing that she would call an early election, placing a bet that voters will give her Conservative Party a strong mandate as her government negotiates the country’s withdrawal from the European Union.
Read more »
PM has confirmed a date and although this needs approved in parliament, labour have previously voiced their support for an early election and so I see little resistance in the house of commons.

May is to make a special announcement at 1115 Uk time and speculation is rife that she will call an early election.  impetus fopr this presumably being an effort to consolidate her position and give her a mandate since she wasn't elected.  a recent poll has also suggested a majority of brits now favour leaving the EU so could be what given her additional confidence.  raising my estimate

Theresa May is due to make a statement in Downing Street at 11.15am amid speculation the Prime Minister could call an early general election. 
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/18/breaking-theresa-may-make-statement-downing-street-1115am1/

Theresa May has a strong advantage in the polls at the moment compared to rival parties. She may want to capitalize on this.  Heavy risks in Scotland and N. Ireland though, so I would not expect this to happen.

Parliament passed approval for Brexit easily, letter announcing departure from EU delivered and white paper released. Although rumblings of no proper plan for brexit from government, support for conservative agenda still seems strong. No reliable coordinated opposition to be able to apply sufficient pressure for snap election.
Dropping the last few points off my guess because this really seems unlikely now.
Passage of time and with Brexit triggered current government must be seen to make a decent attempt at negotiations before going to an election.
not likely now Theresa May has set a date and seems to have an exit-brexit plan. I can't see the British people wanting the uncertainty of a new government leading them into this thing.

May just triggered Article 50, with MPs overwhelmingly backing the Brexit bill which was designed to give the Government the power to invoke Article 50. The House of Commons rejected amendments made by the House of Lords. The bill was then given royal assent. Nothing obvious on the horizon to cause a loss of confidence until negotiations play out.
Very little chance now that Article 50 has been triggered without any turmoil. Govt seems determined to get on with negotiations.
The Gibraltar stuff's making her sound unhinged.
I believe this is now almost impossible. If May would have wanted it she could have connected it to triggering art 50
No sign of this so far
Can't see it happening. Too much to focus on with Brexit to worry about elections
Very Doubtful any of the parliamentary conditions would be met to call for such elections before July.

This seems increasingly unlikely. I can't see the circumstances that would cause this to happen. The Brexit process will not have got very far before then, so there can be no row over the final deal, so no purpose could would arise.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
some chance of Brexit progress hitting a wall that might mean another general election is needed to secure/validate a mandate for the specific proposals and next steps.
Post Brexit Britain desires stability during this tumultuous time. British pols will be cautious delaying changes.

British bookmaker odds indicated a 17 percent probability that Prime Minister Theresa May would call a snap general election after media speculation she could go to the polls. 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-politics-election-idUSKBN16R0UY?il=0

I have increased my chances as May has an excuse now. She can use the Scottish independence calls and the Brexit opposition in the house of lords as the main reasons why she needs a bigger mandate. It will be a once in a lifetime opportunity to wipe out the opposition. Some of the UK press is making a case for it as well.

Persistent rumors that the Torries are considering early elections have appeared recently. They can do it with an orchestrated "no confidence" vote. The purpose would be to increase their majority - Labor is in disarray, and may be the SNP would lose a few seats in Scotland as indyref2 is proving divisive.  If they are going to do it, the time is now - after triggering Art 50 but before negotiations really get under way. Theresa May can say "Give me a clear mandate for Brexit on my terms". But it's a risky move - it's not clear that her terms (no single market etc.) are really that popular.  The Torries may come back with the same slim majority, with LibDems gaining in the big cities. Such an outcome would be perceived as defeat for May, weakening her politically.

Up a bit, in response to Scottish referendum troubles and the potential (which at present remains only that) for the Tories to face a series of embarrassing by-elections if criminal charges are pressed against a number of MPs who were found to have signed off on abuses of maximum spending rules at the 2015 general election. While there are signs that (the £70,000 fine imposed by the Electoral Commission on the Tory Party apart) this may lead to nothing, the chance is not zero. And given the low parliamentary majority and pressures of Brexit, and the almost certain outcome of an increased Tory majority, and despite PM May's repeatedly stated opposition to calling an early election, circumstances may effectively dictate one.
Not with Brexit negotiations, the Trump administration, the threat from Scottish nationalists according to Hague.
No reason for this now that A50 bill has cleared Parliament.

Theresa May Resists Pressure to Call Early British Election to Bolster ‘Brexit’
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/09/world/europe/britain-theresa-may-brexit-european-union.html?ribbon-ad-idx=5&rref=world/europe

1. Brexit huge workload 
2. Would make sense to go to early elections is his is peak advantage vs opposition. But given state of Lab, it appears that Con will have an advantage for some time to come. As long at the advantage is significant, later is better.

There is no need for Mrs May to go to the country to seek a mandate. The Tories are doing very well in the polls, they have just won a by-election (the first sitting government to do so for 35 years) and the majority, whilst small, is sufficient and very unlikely to be reduced significantly before the summer of 2017.  Parliament is consumed by Brexit and it's implications, throwing a general election into the mix would be damaging.  Also, an election would require repeal of the Fixed Term Parliament Act - query how easy that would be in the current environment.
Uncertainty of bi-lateral and multi-lateral nation relationships throughout the world.  And Brixit is a big gamble, regrets are already showing and might grow.  Opinion in Britain is split right now.

May might be tempted to go for an early election after the the by-elections last week showed that Labour and UKIP are not really a threat, but there seems less excuse for overturning the Fixed Term Election law as Labour is not doing anything to block government plans. With Labour clearly in disarray it is difficult to see why they would vote to allow May to call an early election, and at the same time there must be quite a few (50?) Conservative MPs who might be at risk of losing their seats to the LibDems (if you are a Conservative MP who is at risk of loosing to the LibDems the fact that the Conservatives might pick up Labour seats would not be in your personal interest)
If there is to be an election, it is more likely to occur once the shape of the Brexit "deal" is clearer, unlikely until summer 2018.

Corbinski led Labour just lost one bye election and squeaked by in "working class" Smoke on Trent"... Fleet Street buzzers spun it all as a defeat for UKIP... for an anti-Brexit government to take shape the way someone like Phillip Hammond might script it, Tony Bliar will need more time tohis latest visions in to the spongy brains of Labour facing anomie, a/k/a an, uh existential crisis  link  https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2017/feb/23/stoke-and-copeland-byelections-voting-almost-over-as-labour-hope-to-hold-seats-politics-live
Passage of time, lack of noise about a general election.
Down from 20% as nothing seems to be boiling in that direction and setting general elections takes time

I am dropping my forecast to 4%. It is looking less likely than before that an election will take place. Three reasons/updates:
1) today Tony Blair suggested hinted that there could be a coalition of forces in the next election which would aim to block Brexit - this is a threat the May would take very seriously
2) UKIP are looking ever less credible and I imagine will only draw die-hard Brexiteers; one might assume that others would vote Conservative, but there are many people that would never allow themselves to do that (typically the traditional labour voter)
3) it looks increasingly that Liberals will do well at least in Stoke.
While unlikely, either Labour collapse or a need for a further Brexit mandate would make it possible.
Labour is perceived by voters to be weaker than ever, and the Torries are perceived, at the very least, as a beacon of stability.

While I still don't think Theresa May will go to the polls, I do think she must be awfully tempted as the situation within the Labour Party deteriorates. The polling for both the up-coming by-elections are offering a poor prognosis for Labour and if they were to lose both, Corbyn's position would surely be untenable; losing one seat is bad enough. However, balancing this is the fact that it would hardly be desirable to go to the polls just as we are about to go into Brexit negotiations. In addition, May by her very nature is a cautious player and would place the risk ahead of the benefits. And the biggest risk is that the elections would be seen as a re-run of the referendum.

As things stand there are no grounds for calling a general election. However there are a number of key events which could change that.
1) as Brexit has to be debated in the Lords, any blockage there might cause consternation in Downing Street which allied to the points below may cause Theresa May to think about an election If only to get her own mandate
2) there is a key by-election coming up in Stoke upon Trent. If the Liberals do particularly well, and Labour do badly she may tempted to seek her own mandate
3) if Labour do badly in Stoke upon Trent they may be tempted to change their leader. If they do, she might exploit the opportunity to go to the country while Labour are at their most vulnerable.
Down. Got the Brexit law approved.
passed house of commons, doesn't need an early election
Updating due to passage of time and seemingly no opposition to the European Union Bill (allowing govt to trigger Article 50).

Revising down from 7% to 4% because Article 50 passed through the first and second hearings in the Commons.  Now we have the third hearing where MPs begin scrutiny of the "bill" and add amendments [1].

If Brexit negotiations go very badly or there is seen to be a need for a mandate this is a possibility. Also, some on the right think that the time is right to gain a mandate/take advantage of a weak labour party. Would be a gamble though.
I know that there's big mess with Brexit and lots of other matters and early elections are possible, but I think that people wil not make order with it in close time
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
May has broken away from being Maybe so probably remaining.
No reason for the May Government to act so quickly. Would become a second referendum on Brexit.
Time passing and no discussion in that direction makes me think the likelihood must be extremely low (as it would de facto allow another "referendum on Brexit" to emerge.
There are no conditions for an out of cycle election
Reducing probability after article 50 vote and publication of white paper.
Imminent parliamentary vote will virtually seal Brexit.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Under the fixed term parliament act an election could be called if (a) 2/3rds of MPs vote to hold an election or (b) if there's a no confidence vote in the government. With the most recent YouGov polls of 19 Jan 17 showing the public expressing confidence in May's negotiating ability (47% fair amount of confidence vs 38% no confidence), and given that the negotiation are only in the early stages, there's only a very remote chance to set early elections before July 2017

The Fixed Term Parliament Act requires two thirds of the Commons to vote for it to be repealed which is highly unlikely to happen because of how many seats Labour would lose if a general election occurs in 2017.
Legally impossible - Fixed Term Parliament Act cannot just be repealed, primary legislation has to be brought in.
I don't know how the Conservatives would give their own government a vote of no confidence or why 2/3 of MPs would want a snap election. So I don't see how it's possible to call an early election.
Lack of supports for opposition leadership among liberal political elites.
MPs will try to hold their seats for this year, since Brexit process is still underway.

I believe the recent UK court ruling could possibly upset the apple cart here. Are all those MPs who battled against Brexit going to suddenly just go along with it? Were their previous positions just posturing? May, much of the UK press, and many pundits appear to be considering the (positive) vote in Parliament to be a mere foregone conclusion. Corbyn appears to be offering little resistance. I guess I'll go along with all this, but it's hard to see how so many MPs can go from hardcore Remain to acquiescence in such a short period of time. In particular, previously Remain-aligned MPs with solid Remain constituencies face a credibility issue. It's certainly conceivable to me that the process could devolve into ungovernable parties and another (proxy) referendum via MP election. (+4)
Seem very unlikely May needs to - she can wait for the parliament act
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
1. PM May said she would trigger Article 50 in March. 2. Her recent approach to trade agreements and brexit were well received. 3. Early general elections occur 6 months in advance 60% of the time.

It seems unlikely that a general elections date will be set before that day. The parliament is next reviewing the plan. Even if the reject it, there might not be an election.
NO.  There will be too much uncertainty, the conservatives won't be sure enough by then that they'd win.

There is absolutely no wish for a GE in the UK and Theresa May has a good understanding of this. Bar unknown unknowns the only realistic reason for this to happen would be if a large number of MPs decided to vote against triggering Article 50 and May was unable to get the bill through Parliament. If you add up the numbers of northern and Welsh Labour MPs whose seat voted Brexit, and consider that they and some Tory MPs would have to ignore the whip, then it appears unlikely that this would occur.

1 July 2017 is not enough time to feel the pain required to encourage such a drastic measure.  I would have made the probability lower, but there may be some natural disaster that causes a higher sense of urgency.

There is too much for the new May Government to do. Theresa May will dig in and weather the storm from Brtain's exit from EU and pursue her agenda to make progress on issues important to her and the wider country.
There is no need for general elections just now. According to UK citizen, this decision will not cause new election.

Because the Prime Minister, Mrs. May is far too cautious and risk averse to call an election before she has to. She is wrong to miss the opportunity to do so but will rationalise it that the country won't tolerate a third year in a row with an election / referendum.

A new election can be held if a motion of no confidence is passed in the government or a two third super-majority of parliament wants one. I don't think either is likely, even a government backed motion of no confidence.
Few with influence over that seem set to benefit from it.
Leave & Remain are not well aligned with any major parliamentary party except SNP, so this is extremely risky. Effectively a second referendum, so out of the question.
They will end up in a deadlock in the parliament. MPs who are Remainers are going to feel empowered by the Court decision and block a hard Brexit.

Hard to see what advantage the Government  would gain holding a general election this year. Labour is weak but holding a general election before exit terms have been agreed would make the government vulnerable & an election risks opening up divisions within the Conservative party.

Correct from previous 57%. Being "far from the action" makes it difficult to foresee how politicians that I do not know will act. I´ve just read that May was a Remain supporter, that Corbyn has just spoken he is open to support inmigration control on Europeans... What this tells me is that both leaders set before their political positions to their ideas or beliefs (if they were actually beliefs and not just the position they thought would give them more popularity among voters or their party). I now have the impression that they are both weak, mediocre leaders so maybe one or both of them fall, but i do not think general elections will be held. Laboour party trails in the polls and is already bending to topics as vital in the Brexit talks as immigration so May won´t have that much trouble, at least that soon, to negotiate Brexit even if it has to go through Parliament.

The Fixed Term Parliament Act requires a super-majority for an early election. Whilst Corbyn has said in principle he would support an early election he does not command the loyalty of his own party, many of whose MPs would likely be voting to bring forward an election they know they will lose badly. By July 2017 the Brexit process will be very unclear. Theresa May is more likely to see benefit in calling an election once the process is largely completed and she can claim victory (which would suggest close to the end of the 2-year period after invoking Article 50, which is due to happen in March.)
At present doubtful. Due to small minority power and opposition which is in disarray.
No date will be set until article 50 is invoked
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

For now, it appears that Article 50 is more likely than not to be triggered if not before the end of March, then shortly thereafter. The December motion in House of Commons showed strong endorsement for May to proceed. In that case, there is unlikely to be a vote of no confidence required to call a snap election and the Government would be too occupied with Brexit itself to call the election themselves (and would have little reason to).

Mrs May has shown that she absolutely doesn't want any opportunity for Parliament or the electorate to demonstrate a possible majority view supporting Bremain following the Brexit referendum. She's already lost a bi-election to the Lib-Dems with this as the primary issue, abeit in a strong Bremain riding. Article 50 gets activated in March and negotiations will begin - without the benefit of further elector inputs. The wildcard could be Parliament if she were to lose majority support.
Do not see any move for that now as Theresa just took office. Depends on how well her sweeping social reforms go over. To be announced next week. Also how the Brexit negotiations are going.

I firmly disbelieve that a date will be sate for early general elections in the United Kingdom birthed into the median period of 2017. The reason why I suppose this notion is thoroughly because of her rigorous stance against the spread of radicalism, portrayed vehemently through her well knit actions of expelling Abu Qatada, a radicalism cleric earlier in 2014, this stance shadows an overwhelming support against the spread of radicalism in populist Europe . Alluding with that, the top prize Theresa has bagged so far is by spearheading an overcast government shrouded with mysticism on the Brexit palaver as her government plays a neutral role in exiting the E.U , firmly choosing not to exit with a bang , just as Nigel Farage purports but with a soft departure relieving tensions which are going to down on the incumbent government when the side effects of the E.U starts menacing its financial  fragment, then and there, Britons will look up to replacing her with a more populist and economic connoisseur such as what the U.S devoured to and what is in line for Europe. Until then, it is safe to say that no elections will be held in the U.K 0% chance

Traditional logic suggests May should take advantage of the lack of political opposition. However, any election would turn into essentially another Brexit mandate, which would cause the Conservatives to implode.

From past snap elections I would calculate a base rate of around 5% for snap elections in that time frame. Although it was made more difficult by legislation to a prime minister to call for early election, I would revise slighty up because May is lacking a mandate and polls are on her side for a more comfortable majority.

Theresa May has given no indication she wants this and parliamentary opposition to leaving the EU, the probable cause of an early election, is not forthcoming. This is coupled with the legislative complications of staging an early election that may reek of opportunism in the eyes of the public as well as the fact that the new parliamentary boundaries haven't yet been pushed through. The government may not want to risk its fragile majority before it has more favourable boundaries.
There is always a chance, but, with Brexit in mind, it will be harmful for British economy if early elections will take place.
There is no alternative for British voters to the current government in place due to a weak labor party.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Such a date is more likely to be set after July 1st 2017, when negotiations on Brexit will have dragged on for long enough to upset the whole country.
As the path to exit proceeds smoothly - no reason to have change

Given the current thin majority of the Conservative party and the palpable divisions in the British electorate, Theresa May will judge it too risky to call for a general election. She will muddle through all the way to 2020 thanks to the weakness of the opposition and some tactical support from MPs from Northern Ireland
Theresa May would probably go for early elections once the Brexi process starts since she would need to get a popular backing for what she will be agreeing upon during the process.

Revised down slightly from 15% because in my last forecast I completely missed one of the big issues... Article 50!  If Theresa May manages to pass Article 50 through Parliament she will have the mandate to continue to execute this plan for the next 3 years.  Mrs. May ran into the stumbling block of Gina Miller during the Autumn and we should hear back from the Supreme Court in early January.  I fully expect the Supreme Court to side with Miller and Parliament, thus May will then have to force Article 50 through Parliament. The next question is will this pass? If it does, I believe that there is nearly zero chance that May would try for an early General Election.
With the opposition in disarray the conservative party will be tempted to increase its stranglehold on parliament.  Theresa May may try give her government democratic legitimacy with an early vote.
May needs to solidify her position prior to Brexit negotiations.

Since 2011, when a law was passed the restricted when the PM can call snap elections, 0 snap elections have been called. 
but, May, who came in on odd circumstances, because of a recent court ruling, will need favorable MP's to trigger article 50 which allows them to leave Brexit.
If the supreme court reverses that, then the odds of an early election decrease.
Early general elections are set by The Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011--> when the government loses a confidence motion or when a 2/3 majority of MPs vote in favour. That is 434 votes.

Looking at the pros and cons of a snap election for May, her party and the Brexit process and the fact that the court ruling does not let May not consult parlament regarding the brexit talks, I believe there will be a snap election in the UK (current polls show his hand in parlament would be strenghten), although my main concern in this question would be the timing: I believe it will be shortly after invoking article 50, which is meant to be in March but these kind of matters are rarely earlier than stated and usually delayed, which would give little room before 1st of July.

As the filing of the A50 comes near and a hard exit becomes more of a likelihood, more financial concerns will be rumored to be moving a large percentage of their operations off shore. This along with the global political situation will eventually lead to the call for a snap election but it will not happen by 7/1.
Breixit exit will become more problematic
I now think it is less likely as why would Turkeys vote for Christmas, see @pietrokc
Updating from 10% not so much in response to new data but because I have thought things through a bit more.

Muslims in England will create an uprising to thwart or delay any such election.

Rude Awakening for the English folk that voted for Brexit, the reality is bigger than the demagoguery, pain is starting to trickle down (9 like trickle down economics, usually is pain at the bottom) the EU economic impact is starting to really hurt, so before an election is called, the path will be built to stop the full exit, that is going to drag many negotiations including the call for a new election, I prefer to be wrong in the absolute in this one. Suffering for the unnecessary reason of idiocy, this too can be stopped, so I hope that some sanity return to the nativists.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Because the next election by statute is not due until 2020, the official,opposition do not want an election in the near future, the Lib-Dems do but have no leverage, ditto UKIP, the SNP don't want an election, they cannot improve their current position, and Theresa May has good, competent control and sufficient support to continue and has shown no inclination to force an early election. So, no,  an early date will not be set before 1/7/17.
Forecasting down. Time until question resolution: 6 months, 6 days.
She might want to have an early election, but things could change very quickly with Brexit and go very badly so she might want to hang on until it's clear where the article 50 negotiations are going.

Obviously proceedings with Article 50 are important. Also interesting are by elections, if Consevatives do well, especially Copeland, then temptation will follow. However I see May being extremely reluctant.

I've revised my view far towards Yes after more research into this matter.  The first issue to consider is whether this is even feasible.  Assumption One: The Conservative Party would be the political player that makes this happen (as we shall see, no other party has enough seats or sway to make this happen right now).  So, the Tories have three options: 1) Vote of no-confidence in itself, 2) Vote for early GE through super-majority, 3) Repeal FPTA, 4) Pass a bill bypassing FTPA for just this *one* time.   I think that path 4) is the most likely option since it is the most achievable and the option that loses the least political face.  Option 2) seems impossible by the date set.  Option 1) and 3) are possible but seem a lot harder to rationalize (some might plump for option 3) over 4), they amount to the same end point --> we could just clump 3) and 4) together and say "pass bill allowing GE", doesn't matter!).

The outlook and world politics are changing in all countries. Farage will step up and wll be the candidate fighting migration, but the date for an early election is too soon. Election dates will be later as the UK is too busy with Brexit.
Not if Chancellor Hammond can help it.  Then too, Corbynski doesn't have his ducks in a row, and add to that the Trump factor. Do we have a post-truth "Iron Lady' 2.0 in the making?

TM's cautious approach makes it seem unlikely that she'll instigate any route to a GE so early in brexit processs. State of opposition and risk to remainer MPs makes it seem unlikely that MPs will vote with supermajority. FTP Act extremely unlikely to be repealed - V unusual to repeal acts. Vote of no confidence most likely route, but still unlikely as it seems that Parliament wants to hold gov feet to the fire rather than frustrate exit process. Parlimentary politics has had a turbulent time and probably doesn't want to force a GE on the electorate, and electorate don't seem to be enthused by prospect. But things are happening quickly and unexpectedly, so not a complete outside chance (e.g. 1%). Start at 15% consensus, lower to 10% to approx strip out forecasts â‰¥50%.
the pm is cautious and measured. She will announce in october

I am starting at 10% because of the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011. This law specified that parliaments run for five years and early elections cannot be held on a whim. Under this law there are only two ways to call an early election: (1) if a motion for an early general election is agreed either by at least two-thirds of the whole House or without division; or (2) if a motion of no confidence is passed and no alternative government is confirmed by the Commons within 14 days. I cannot see the first scenario because that requires agreement from both the tories and labour, and Corbyn wouldn't know a political deal if one slapped him. The second seems marginally more likely if triggering Brexit in parliament causes a tory split.
Seems a very remote possibility as labour doesn't want it - they will loose big time - May has said she doesn't want it and it probably needs a obstruction to article 50 in March to trigger it.
Theresa May has the mandate to finish the negotiation. Unless there is a end-of-the road situation I do not foresee elections
May will be looking at plunging popularity as she heads into early difficulties with Brexit, unless her majority evaporates completely she will want to delay elections until a deal is finalised.
PM May will not forsake a chance to capitalise on Labour's woes. Also, an election will distract MP:s from parliamentary work aiming for a bigger say on brexit.

Start - 50:50
Trigger would be a frustrated Brexit Vote but unlikely following majority vote by MP's that they would trigger art 50. (-20%)
Labour not in strong position as an opposition party - weak leadership, no coherent policy. UKIP threat (-20%)

"Unlikely because in order to do so one of three things has to happen (a) the 2011 Fixed Term Parliament Act would need to be repealed (b) The House of Commons has to have a vote of no confidence in the government (c) two-thirds of the House of Commons has to vote for a new general election. 
Before 2011 the PM could call a general election using the Royal Prerogative but not since. 
The government could in theory win a no confidence vote in itself, but that would seem to be a very odd thing to do (i.e. admit that although the government has a majority it is not confidence in its own ability to govern?) Trying to call a no confidence vote in itself would require the government to have almost full support of its MPs and/or all non-Tory MPs to not oppose it. 
There are obvious reasons why many MPs would be unwilling to vote for an early general election. The MPs were elected on their parties manifestos which reflected the general policies of their parties. Any early election would almost certainly become another referendum on Brexit. As has been seen with by-elections since July voters are no longer going to vote along predictable party lines, so a large but unpredictable percentage of sitting MPs would be at risk of being voted out. Tory MPs that support Brexit in places that voted to Remain would be at risk (as per Richmond Park). Tory MPs that supported Remain in places that voted to Leave might be at risk from UKIP, as might Labour MPs. Local tactical voting pacts (as at Richmond) might increase the risk of sitting Tories losing. It is unlikely that many MPs who thought they were in a safe seat would want to risk an early election. 
At the moment there appears to be a majority of MPs who want a "soft" Brexit, an election could produce a House much more in favour of a "hard" Brexit. So it seems unlikely that "softs" would want to vote for a new election which might produce a very "hard" Brexit (I am not suggesting this would not be democratic, but that MPs are human and are not going to want to help Mrs May get a result they don't like.) 
To repeal the 2011 Act would require similar voting in the Commons with the addition of getting the repeal through the Lords which is both unlikely and would take some time. 
To vote for a general election would require not only the Tories to vote for it, but would require many opposition MPs to support the government. While in theory its possible to goad the opposition into voting for a general election that the government is sure will strengthen the government and weaken the opposition, it would be like getting the turkeys to vote for Christmas. I am sure that even the most inept opposition would be be able to think up a good reason why it should not commit suicide in order to give Mrs May a bigger majority."
All these votes haven't exactly been working out for the Conservatives (or Labor), have they
Elections used as a proxy second referendum, detailing terms of brexit
I think Mrs.May will try to run her government the maximum time available until she realises (in 2018) that calling election is the best decision

Unlikely because in order to do so one of three things has to happen (a) the 2011 Fixed Term Parliament Act would need to be repealed (b) The House of Commons has to have a vote of no confidence in the government (c) two-thirds of the House of Commons has to vote for a new general election. 
Before 2011 the PM could call a general election using the Royal Prerogative but not since. 
The government could in theory win a no confidence vote in itself, but that would seem to be a very odd thing to do (i.e. admit that although the government has a majority it is not confidence in its own ability to govern?) Trying to call a no confidence vote in itself would require the government to have almost full support of its MPs and/or all non-Tory MPs to not oppose it. 
There are obvious reasons why many MPs would be unwilling to vote for an early general election. The MPs were elected on their parties manifestos which reflected the general policies of their parties. Any early election would almost certainly become another referendum on Brexit. As has been seen with by-elections since July voters are no longer going to vote along predictable party lines, so a large but unpredictable percentage of sitting MPs would be at risk of being voted out. Tory MPs that support Brexit in places that voted to Remain would be at risk (as per Richmond Park). Tory MPs that supported Remain in places that voted  to Leave might be at risk from UKIP, as might Labour MPs. Local tactical voting pacts (as at Richmond) might increase the risk of sitting Tories losing. It is unlikely that many MPs who thought they were in a safe seat would want to risk an early election. 
At the moment there appears to be a majority of MPs who want a "soft" Brexit, an election could produce a House much more in favour of a "hard" Brexit. So it seems unlikely that "softs" would want to vote for a new election which might produce a very "hard" Brexit (I am not suggesting this would not be democratic, but that MPs are human and are not going to want to help Mrs May get a result they don't like.)  
To repeal the 2011 Act would require similar voting in the Commons with the addition of getting the repeal through the Lords which is both unlikely and would take some time. 
To vote for a general election would require not only the Tories to vote for it, but would require many opposition MPs to support the government. While in theory its possible to goad the opposition into voting for a general election that the government is sure will strengthen the government and weaken the opposition, it would be like getting the turkeys to vote for Christmas. I am sure that even the most inept opposition would be be able to think up a good reason why it should not commit suicide in order to give Mrs May a bigger majority.

After sleeping on my assessment, I realized a made a simple foolish mistake. My first forecast was based on the question "Will PM May call for early elections before 1 July 2017?" Instead of the correct "Before 1 July 2017, will a date be set for early general elections in the UK." This implies that that the parliament has come to a decision to vote and was then able to pass it with 2/3 majority (extremely unlikely)and then the Queen set a date. There are conditions in the UK suggesting a desire for an early election is possible - certainly moreso than in most years. I might give a somewhat generous chance for an early election to be called under pre-2011 rules, but these rules set the bar very high even if one is desired. 10% chance reflects my lack of knowledge of UK politics - 50% chance of a desire for an early election, 20% chance conditional on desire of actually making it happen.

Based on the limited research I have done, it seems that PM May is a bit of a traditionalist. Even though today the court ruled that she could not enact Article 50 without it going through the parliament, the idea she would call for an early election without first trying to pass the article with the current parliament which currently has a majority (although not a strong one) in her favor on this subject, seems incongruent with her leadership style. She has stated in the past that she would like to start the Brexit talks by the end of March 2017 (ref: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/03/world/europe/brexit-talks-march-theresa-may-britain.html). This would lead me to believe that there would be no call for an early general election before that time (The government is going to appeal the ruling of the lower courts to their higher courts anyway so that will take time also). This leaves us with only April through June for the parliament to discuss Article 50 and how to best go about "Brexiting". Just as a little kicker for that short amount of time for the Parliament to discuss this complex topic, assuming they have roughly the same amount of days off as they did for last year (ref: http://www.parliament.uk/about/faqs/house-of-commons-faqs/business-faq-page/recess-dates/) they will be on vacation for roughly 41 of the 91 days of April through June. If PM May thinks that the Parliament can push through a complex and VERY emotionally charged and controversial Article in a Parliament that is not a very heavy majority for any party (ref: http://www.parliament.uk/mps-lords-and-offices/lords/composition-of-the-lords/ and http://www.parliament.uk/mps-lords-and-offices/mps/current-state-of-the-parties/), then I would argue that she is either an eternal optimist or naÃ¯ve, which I would suspect neither of her. Based on that I would think it will be very unlikely to see a call for an early general election before 1 July 2017. Another roadblock to this is that in order for a early general election to be called, according to the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011 there needs to be either a vote of "No confidence in Her Majesty's Government" or there needs to a motion passed by 2/3 of the MPs (to include vacant seats). Mathematically, this would be quite difficult for the current majority party (the conservatives) because even if they could get EVERY vote except the Labor votes, they would still fall short of a 2/3 vote. Considering all these roadblocks, I am forecasting this as a 5% yes.
The skittishness of the electorate on display in the recent by-election seems a good reason not to go to an election.

- Theresa May's effective commons majority is tiny, and unstable given number of potentially miscreant MPs (e.g. George Osborne's network...)
- TM wants to seek legitimacy for her gov't and Brexit plan

Unlikely before invocation of Article 50. As a negotiating strategy, the U.K. has little incentive to rush Article 50.

Looking through history, I can only find one instance of a government with a reasonable majority calling an early general election - 1923. The circumstances then were a change of leader, and the government wanting a fresh mandate. While this circumstance is shared now, there have been plenty of changes of Prime Minister without an immediate election - I make the record roughly 1-5 against in the last 100 years.

Forecasts suggest that in Q2 2017 there may be a recession triggered by the collapse of the shadow banking system in China. It would be unusual for the UK government to call an election at a time like that.

The Supreme Court may yet over-rule the High Court. Even if it doesn't Parliament will be under great popular pressure to vote in accordance with the will of the people. If either of these steps do not resolve the situation, calling an election is still a very high-risk strategy and quite probably won't happen.

The High Court ruling (unlikely to be overturned by the Supreme Court) means that Parliament will, in the end, decide the nature of Brexit. Given that the public is also split almost 50/50 between EU immigration controls and acces to the EU market (mutually exclusive), it is clear that what Britons want from Brexit is more nuanced. The only way I see this to be resolved is through early elections.
There is only marginal upside to the May government calling an early election and large potential risk. 1% chance. One in a hundred only because I can't mark one in a thousand.
Of all of the early elections called over the past 100 years only two would qualify based on 2011 legislation. Leaning slightly higher than this for now.

PM May has pledged to trigger Article 50 early in 2017 and that will be the focus of her efforts over the next 12 months. Although her majority is small there is no certainty that an early election would help, as Brexit is accepted only partly along party lines. The opposition is currently too weak to be a serious threat to her preferred legislation, as it forms. While this situation persists resistance from secure Conservative colleagues and the Lords may be a greater issue. Moreover, if May can hang on till 2020, constituency boundary changes are likely to favour the Conservatives.
The Conservative Party will try to take advantage of Labours current troubles, and possibly win a mandate for their brexit-strategy (such as it is)

government  will want a national mandate after brexit

1)   As of now an early election is unnecessary.
2)  Public dislikes for early elections due to wastage of tax payers money.
3)  Under the UK Parliament's Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011, the Prime Minister can no longer make a call regarding general election, even if PM does, then the PM has a daunting task of overcoming parliamentary and political hurdles before anything can be brought for discussion in the House of Commons to be agreed upon and passed as an act or something like that.

If parliament can't pass some sort of Brexit plan, then I don't see much alternative to going back to the polls.  It looks like the courts are going to say Brexit needs parliamentary approval, and I don't see that as much better than a coin toss.
